channel.title: AppSignal
channel.description: The AppSignal blog. Product updates, Ruby Magic, Elixir Alchemy, AppSignal Academy and more.

item.title: How to Scale Ruby on Rails Applications
item.description: Check out some ways to scale your Ruby on Rails applications, including with caching and background workers.

item.title: Build a Table Editor with Trix and Turbo Frames in Rails
item.description: Let's build a table editor in a Rails application using ActionText's Trix editor, and use Turbo Frames to customize your table.

item.title: Improve Code in Your Ruby Application with RubyCritic
item.description: Let's take a look at RubyCritic and dig into RubyCritic's reports.

item.title: Security Best Practices for Your Rails Application
item.description: Ensure your Rails application stays secure by following some best practices and habits.

item.title: Debugging in Ruby with AppSignal
item.description: Learn how you can use AppSignal to log and debug your Ruby application.

item.title: JIT Compilers for Ruby and Rails: An Overview
item.description: Find out about the different JIT compilers for Ruby — YJIT, MJIT, and TenderJIT — and their benefits.

item.title: Monitor Ruby Application Performance with Magic Dashboards
item.description: Let's monitor and fix performance issues within a Ruby on Rails application using magic dashboards.

item.title: An Introduction to Ractors in Ruby
item.description: Discover when and why you should use ractors, and build a ractor in Ruby.

item.title: A Deep Dive into Memory Leaks in Ruby
item.description: In the second and final part of our series on memory leaks in Ruby, let's dive a bit deeper into some tools you can use.

item.title: Connect a Ruby on Rails App with React in a Monolith
item.description: Learn about the three main types of app architecture, then connect React with your monolith Ruby on Rails app.

item.title: Monitor Alpine Linux ARM Hosts with AppSignal
item.description: We've launched ARM support for machines running Alpine Linux.

item.title: AppSignal for Ruby Gem 3.1: MRI VM Magic Dashboard
item.description: AppSignal's Ruby gem 3.1 which adds a Magic Dashboard for MRI VM stats is here!

item.title: How to Track Down Memory Leaks in Ruby
item.description: Let's explore how Ruby manages memory, garbage collection, and how to uncover a leak, in the first of this two-part series on memory leaks in Ruby.

item.title: Deploy Your Ruby on Rails App Using Capistrano
item.description: Find out how to configure Capistrano in your Rails app, then deploy the app.

item.title: Get Started with Hotwire in Your Ruby on Rails App
item.description: Learn the basics of Hotwire and how to use it in your Rails app.

item.title: State Machines in Ruby: An Introduction
item.description: Let's build a simple state machine in Ruby and use the state machines gem.

item.title: Add Feature Flags in Ruby on Rails with Flipper
item.description: Find out how feature flags function in principle and get started with feature flags using the Flipper gem.

item.title: An Introduction to Polymorphism in Ruby on Rails
item.description: Learn how you can implement polymorphism in your Rails application for cleaner code.

item.title: Using Scientist to Refactor Critical Ruby on Rails Code
item.description: Migrate, refactor, and change critical Ruby production code with confidence using the Scientist gem.

item.title: Bootstrapping with Ruby on Rails Generators and Templates
item.description: Let's explore the basics of Rails generators and templates, then examine how to customize your Rails app with templates.

item.title: 5 Tips to Design Ruby on Rails Transactions the Right Way
item.description: Check out these 5 tips to ensure your transactions are readable and well-designed in your Ruby on Rails app.

item.title: The Perils of Parallel Testing in Ruby on Rails
item.description: Parallel tests can help speed up your tests in Rails, but be aware of the possible pitfalls.

item.title: Import Maps Under the Hood in Rails 7
item.description: Learn how to install JavaScript libraries with import maps and how import maps work under the hood in Rails 7.

item.title: Delayed Job vs. Sidekiq: Which Is Better?
item.description: Let's take a look at the pros and cons of Delayed Job and Sidekiq, two major job processing systems for Rails apps.

item.title: How to Keep Database Table Sizes Down and Prevent Data Bloat
item.description: Watch out for data hoarding, which can cause database bloat. Here's how to keep your database table sizes down.

item.title: Test and Optimize Your Ruby on Rails Database Performance
item.description: Explore three common ways to discover and test database performance problems in Rails, and seven ways to optimize performance.

item.title: Next Level Ruby on Rails Application Monitoring with AppSignal
item.description: Let's run through adding custom instrumentation and monitoring to a Ruby on Rails application.

item.title: AppSignal’s Top 5 Ruby Posts in 2021
item.description: Let's look back at our top 5 Ruby posts this year, with a special mention thrown in for good measure.

item.title: What's New in Rails 7
item.description: Rails 7 is coming very soon. Let's look at what we can expect from the release.

item.title: Ruby on Rails Application Monitoring with AppSignal
item.description: In the first of this two-part series, we'll set up monitoring for a Ruby on Rails application with AppSignal.

item.title: Practical Garbage Collection Tuning in Ruby
item.description: Explore how to implement and customize garbage collection in Ruby.

item.title: Optimistic Locking in Rails REST APIs
item.description: Implement optimistic locking in Rails APIs to avoid potentially critical issues.

item.title: How to Reduce Memory Bloat in Ruby
item.description: Memory bloat can be a serious issue in Ruby. This article explores two common causes of memory bloat and how you can overcome them.

item.title: Responsible Monkeypatching in Ruby
item.description: Monkeypatching can be a great way to improve existing code if used right. Let's find out how.

item.title: Ruby's Hidden Gems: Bullet
item.description: Let's dive into Bullet and find out how it can help you identify some database-related problems.

item.title: An Introduction to Pattern Matching in Ruby
item.description: Find out about pattern matching in Ruby, what it does, and how it can help improve code readability.

item.title: General Ruby on Rails Problems and Takeaways
item.description: In this last part of the Rails Patterns and Anti-patterns series, I'll be going over the most common problems I've encountered while building and shipping Ruby on Rails applications.

item.title: How to Monitor and Optimize Your Database Performance: A Practical Guide
item.description: In this post, we'll dive into the database part of your architecture to show how you can monitor and optimize your database performance.

item.title: Performance, Stress, and Load Tests in Rails
item.description: Let's jump into theoretical and practical aspects of performance testing in Rails.

item.title: Three Ways To Avoid Duplicate Sidekiq Jobs
item.description: Sidekiq is used to handle background processing. Whatever your background jobs may be, you'll eventually run into duplicate jobs. Let's see how to de-duplicate them.

item.title: Linting Ruby Code
item.description: Let's take a look at what linting is and a few problems that come with it.

item.title: Ruby on Rails Controller Patterns and Anti-patterns
item.description: In this part of the series on Rails patterns and anti-patterns, we are going to analyze the final part of the MVC (Model-View-Controller) design pattern — the Controller.

item.title: The Easiest Way to Monitor Ruby: Automatic Instrumentation
item.description: Automatic instrumentation enables AppSignal app to digest, process, monitor, and show you the graphs and dashboards you need the most.

item.title: Announcing AppSignal for Ruby Gem 3.0!
item.description: We're very happy to present you with version 3.0 of AppSignal for Ruby - a new major release for the Ruby gem. 🎉

item.title: Troubleshooting ActiveRecord Performance
item.description: You usually don't need to worry about AcriveRecord and its inner workings. This post comes in handy when performance issues arise and you have to start worrying about it.

item.title: Using Webpacker in Your Ruby on Rails Application — a Deep Dive
item.description: Let's take a deep dive into Webpacker and see how the tool works under the hood.

item.title: Ruby on Rails View Patterns and Anti-patterns
item.description: Rails views are sometimes amazing and fast, and at other times, they can have all sorts of issues. If you want to increase confidence over how you handle your views, then this blog post is for you.

item.title: RBS: A New Ruby 3 Typing Language in Action
item.description: Let's discover the differences and similarities between Sorbet and the recently released RBS through some practical examples.

item.title: How to Use Mixins and Modules in Your Ruby on Rails Application
item.description: Find out how to create and mix modules into other classes and discover what are the benefits from using them in a Ruby on Rails application.

item.title: Microservices Monitoring: Using Namespaces for Data Structuring
item.description: Microservices pose unique challenges for error reporting and instrumentation. Today, we’ll explore the best way to monitor them using namespaces in AppSignal.

item.title: Top 5 Ruby Blog Posts in 2020 from AppSignal
item.description: Check out the most appreciated Ruby posts on our blog in 2020.

item.title: New Magic Dashboard for Ruby on Rails: ActionMailer
item.description: We've made monitoring ActionMailer better - with a magic dashboard.

item.title: Setting Up AppSignal Monitoring for a Ruby on Rails Application
item.description: Find out how to integrate AppSignal into a Rails application in our latest video.

item.title: Building a Multi-tenant Ruby on Rails App With Subdomains
item.description: Discover different approaches to multitenancy and build a simple app with multiple tenants where each tenant will have its subdomain.

item.title: Ruby on Rails Model Patterns and Anti-patterns
item.description: If you're struggling with models, this blog post is for you. We will quickly go through the process of putting your models on a diet and finish strongly with some things to avoid when writing migrations.

item.title: Structuring Monitoring Data in Monolithic Applications With Namespaces
item.description: Namespaces help you make sense of what’s happening in your application. Knowing how they work is especially useful for large monolithic projects.

item.title: Monitoring Any System with StatsD and AppSignal's Standalone Agent
item.description: To extend monitoring everywhere and have all data in a single place, check out our standalone agent.

item.title: Rails Concerns: To Concern Or Not To Concern
item.description: Should you be concerned about Rails concerns?

item.title: Introduction to Ruby on Rails Patterns and Anti-patterns
item.description: Dig into the basics of design patterns and anti-patterns.

item.title: Scaling Queue Workers Efficiently with AppSignal Metrics
item.description: Let's use some simple math and performance data to find our optimal worker count, based on the work waiting in the queue.

item.title: Using Service Objects in Ruby on Rails
item.description: Find out what service objects are and why you should use them.

item.title: Dissecting Rails Migrations
item.description: Let's break down a migration process and find out how to write an effective migration.

item.title: The Citadel Architecture at AppSignal
item.description: Check out how AppSignal uses the Citadel pattern and how our system works.

item.title: Changing the Approach to Debugging in Ruby with TracePoint
item.description: Learn more about TracePoint and how it makes code tell us what it's doing.

item.title: Facade Pattern in Rails for Performance and Maintainability
item.description: Find out how and why you should use a software design pattern named Facade.

item.title: Building a Rails App With Multiple Subdomains
item.description: Learn how to build a Rails app that can support multiple subdomains.

item.title: Getting Started With System Tests in Rails With Minitest
item.description: Dive into instances when generic methods are worth replacing with specific alternatives, illustrated by cleaning up strings.

item.title: Rails is Fast: Optimize Your View Performance
item.description: You'll learn some effective performance and optimization techniques that you can use to speed up your Rails app.

item.title: Pros and Cons of Using structure.sql in Your Ruby on Rails Application
item.description: Discover the major differences and benefits of using structure.sql vs schema.rb in your Ruby on Rails application.

item.title: Top 10 AppSignal Blog Posts in 2019
item.description: Check out the most appreciated posts on our blog in 2019.

item.title: Configurable Ruby Modules: The Module Builder Pattern
item.description: Explore how to implement configurable modules in Ruby — a technique sometimes referred to as the Module Builder Pattern.

item.title: Sidekiq Optimization and Monitoring
item.description: Where we look at lessons learned in monitoring and performance, and go through some things that seem simple at first, but turn out to be a bit more complex.

item.title: Ruby Templating: Baking an Interpreter
item.description: In this post, we'll bake our own Interpreter, bringing the Templating series together with a lot of sticky stroop.

item.title: The Inherited Hook Method in Ruby - and More Parenting Lessons
item.description: Today, we will explore the inherited hook method and dive into preventing inheritance

item.title: Type Checking in Ruby — Check Yo Self Before You Wreck Yo Self
item.description: A splash into Duck Typing, gradual typing and enjoying Sorbet on a typical summer day

item.title: Cleaning Up Ruby Strings 13 Times Faster
item.description: In this post we dive into when generic methods are worth replacing with specific alternatives. Illustrated by cleaning up strings.

item.title: Digging Deeper into Ruby Templating: The Parser
item.description: With the lexer in place, let’s move on to the next step: The parser.

item.title: Brewing our own Template Lexer in Ruby
item.description: For our dive into templating, we end up writing our own lexer.

item.title: The Ultimate Checklist to Properly Internationalize Devise
item.description: The checklist I wish existed when I discovered the complexities of Internationalising Devise

item.title: Inside Enumeration in Ruby
item.description: We dive even deeper into enumeration by looking at the internal implementation and implementing our own versions of the `Enumerable` module and the `Enumerator` class.

item.title: Up the Ancestor Chain with method_missing
item.description: In this post we'll follow a method and travel all the way up the ancestor chain

item.title: Ruby's Hidden Gems -Delegator and Forwardable
item.description: In today's exploration of Ruby's standard library, we're going to look at delegation through Ruby's Delegator and Forwardable classes.

item.title: Kafka and Ruby, a Sidekiq Lovestory
item.description: The choices we made in our own stack: connecting Kafka and Ruby through Sidekiq.

item.title: Learning by building, a Background Processing System in Ruby
item.description: In this edition of Ruby Magic, we'll implement our very own background processing system to offload potentially slow tasks as a peek into background job libraries like Sidekiq.

item.title: Object Marshalling in Ruby
item.description: In this article, we’re going to dive into object marshalling, the Marshall module, and compare the `_dump` and `self._load` methods.

item.title: Ruby's Hidden Gems, StringScanner
item.description: Ruby comes with an excellent standard library. Parts of which are unknown, almost hidden gems, like today's subject Stringscanner

item.title: Diving into Ruby's #dup and #clone
item.description: How #dup and #clone differ and how they work under the hood, triggered by a practical example.

item.title: Unraveling Classes, Instances and Metaclasses in Ruby
item.description: Through examining metaclasses, we'll learn how class and instance methods work in Ruby.

item.title: An instrumental intro to GraphQL with Ruby
item.description: We'll learn about GraphQL by making an application about music

item.title: Bindings and Lexical Scope in Ruby
item.description: In this edition of Ruby Magic, we’ll show how scope works in Ruby’s methods and closures. We’ll also take a peek at how ERB uses the binding object to render templates.

item.title: Don't be mean: Statistical means and percentiles 101
item.description: A post about the statistics we use at AppSignal and how they work.

item.title: Fibers and Enumerators in Ruby - Turning Blocks Inside Out
item.description: In this edition of Ruby Magic, we shine a light on Enumerable and Fiber to explain flow controlling enumerables and turning blocks inside out.

item.title: Testing Asynchronous Threads in Ruby
item.description: Using a mental model with a Batman metaphor we explain testing asynchonous threads in Ruby

item.title: Building a Ruby C Extension From Scratch
item.description: In this edition of Ruby Magic, we'll show you how to use code written in C from Ruby.

item.title: The innards of a RubyGem
item.description: Share code with yourself or others by utilizing the RubyGems ecosystem.

item.title: ActiveRecord vs. Ecto Part Two
item.description: The second part of the ActiveRecord vs. Ecto series, in which Batman and Batgirl fight over querying databases and we compare apples and oranges.

item.title: The Magic of Class-level Instance Variables
item.description: Even classes are objects in Ruby. In this edition of Ruby Magic, we'll look at class-level instance variables by creating a module for wrapping an object's methods.

item.title: ActiveRecord vs. Ecto Part One
item.description: In part one of this two-part series, we'll compare ActiveRecord and Ecto by looking at how they handle database schemas and migration.

item.title: #to_s or #to_str? Explicitly casting vs. implicitly coercing types in Ruby
item.description: We'll look into difference between explicit casting and implicit coercing in Ruby, and the difference between typecasting Leonard Nimoy and Michael Keaton.

item.title: Differences Between #nil?, #empty?, #blank?, and #present?
item.description: In this article, we'll refresh your knowledge by looking at the differences between #nil?, #empty?, #blank? and #present? in Ruby and Rails.

item.title: Closures in Ruby: Blocks, Procs and Lambdas
item.description: In Ruby Magic we love to dive into the magic behind the things we use every day to understand how they work. In this edition, we’ll explore the differences between blocks, procs and lambdas.

item.title: Push and Pub/Sub in Ruby
item.description: In this episode of AppSignal Academy, we'll dive into real time updating and toy around with building a minimal WebSocket server to look at how it works under the hood.

item.title: Rails Collection Caching
item.description: In this article, we'll take a look at how Rails collection caching works and how we can use it to speed up large collection rendering.

item.title: Changing the Way Ruby Creates Objects
item.description: In this edition of Ruby Magic, we'll look at how Ruby creates and initializes objects and how we can modify the default behavior.

item.title: Generating Random Numbers in Ruby
item.description: Random numbers are useful for a variety of purposes such as in gaming, encryption and building simulations. In this article, we'll look at the various ways you can generate random numbers in Ruby.

item.title: Ruby Magic Summer Special: The Best of AppSignal Academy
item.description: The best of AppSignal Academy: 5 of our favorite Ruby articles

item.title: JavaScript-sprinkled Rails Applications
item.description: Using JavaScript sprinkes to load dynamic or user-specific content after the rest of the page is directly served from the cache.

item.title: Under the Hood: “Slurping” and Streaming Files in Ruby
item.description: Streaming files line by line is often preferred over “slurping” the whole content at once. In this edition of Ruby Magic, we'll learn how streaming files and other I/O streams works in Ruby.

item.title: Custom Exceptions in Ruby
item.description: Almost everything in Ruby is an object and errors are no exception.

item.title: Caching counters with ActiveRecord's counter caches
item.description: Instead of counting the associated records in the database every time the page loads, ActiveRecord’s counter caching feature allows storing the counter and updating it every time an associated object is created or removed.

item.title: Ruby's redo, retry and next keywords
item.description: We've talked about the retry keyword before. Its little-known counterpart redo works similarly, but reruns loop iterations instead of whole blocks.

item.title: Ruby's magical Enumerable module
item.description: Ruby's handling of enumerables is one of it's most magical features. In this episode of Ruby Magic, we'll learn how these work and how to make your own objects tenumerable.

item.title: Speeding up your app’s navigation with Turbolinks
item.description: Turbolinks is an optimization that increases the perceived performance by being smart about switching pages and reloading assets in your app.

item.title: Ensuring execution, retrying failures and reraising exceptions in Ruby
item.description: Besides `rescue`, Ruby has more ways to handle exceptions. We'll use the `retry` and `ensure` keywords and reraised exceptions to build a resilient web API client.

item.title: Client-side caching in Rails: conditional GET requests
item.description: Rails' conditional GET support allows you to store rendered pages in the user's browser cache to reuse them for repeated requests instead of rendering the same view multiple times.

item.title: ActiveRecord performance: the N+1 queries antipattern
item.description: The N+1 queries problem is a common, but usually easy to spot, performance antipattern that's sometimes caused by lazy loading associations.

item.title: Rails' built-in cache stores: an overview
item.description: Rails' cache stores can store the data in memory, Memcached, Redis, or even straight to disk. But which of the different cache stores is best for which situation?

item.title: Rescuing exceptions in Ruby
item.description: A raised exception can be rescued to prevent it from crashing your application once it reaches to top of the call stack. In this article, we'll examine different ways to rescue exceptions.

item.title: Russian doll caching in Rails
item.description: Russian doll caching explained with a code example. By nesting cache fragments, views are almost never rendered completely. Even when the data changes, most of the rendered pages are served straight from the cache.

item.title: Understanding system load and load averages
item.description: The load average tells you the load your system has been under. In this article, we'll discuss how it's calculated, how to read the returned values, and when to be alarmed.

item.title: Fragment caching in Rails
item.description: Rails' built-in fragment caching is used to store pre-rendered view fragments, so they don't need to be rendered again unless their contents need to change.

item.title: Exceptions in Ruby
item.description: An exception is a signal that's sent when the program doesn't know how to deal with a specific situation. In this introduction, we'll explain what exceptions are, and how to raise one, and how to rescue your app from crashes caused by exceptions.

item.title: Benchmarking Ruby Code
item.description: When working on an important piece of code in your codebase, running benchmarks to compare different implementations can give more insight into their execution speeds.

item.title: Inspecting data in Ruby
item.description: Most exceptions are caused by unexpected data being passed to methods that work fine otherwise, so it's often useful to trace a piece of data through your application to find the cause of an error.

item.title: Syntactic sugar methods in Ruby
item.description: Ever hear about Ruby's syntactic sugar, but never knew what it meant or how to use it? In this article we'll explore just how we can use it to our advantage.

item.title: Debugging exceptions in Rails
item.description: Rails' logs provide a great way to debug issues. Although the raised exceptions don't always make a lot of sense on first glance, carefully retracting the steps the code took to get to the issue is a great way to find out the source of errors in your app.

item.title: Reading and understanding Ruby stack traces
item.description: The stack trace gives you a dump of the current state of your call stack whenever an exception is raised, and is helpful in finding out where things went wrong.

item.title: Track cache hits with custom metrics
item.description: Track how well your caching is optimized by using custom metrics.

item.title: A look at how Ruby interprets your code
item.description: A look at how Ruby interprets your code and how you can use this knowledge to your advantage.

item.title: Concurrency Deep Dive: Event loops
item.description: A deep dive into achieving concurrency using an event loop.

item.title: Concurrency Deep Dive: Multi-threading
item.description: A deep dive into achieving concurrency using threads.

item.title: Concurrency Deep Dive: Multi-process
item.description: A deep dive into achieving concurrency using multi-process.

item.title: Running Rack: How Ruby HTTP servers run Rails apps
item.description: After starting work on a simple HTTP server a while back, we're diving back in to learn how to handle POST requests and what we need to do to serve a Rails application.

item.title: Escaping characters in Ruby
item.description: Escaping characters in Ruby can be quite confusing. In this post we'll cover the power of the backslash symbol \ and how you can use it.

item.title: Building a 30 line HTTP server in Ruby
item.description: Web servers, and HTTP in general, might seem difficult to understand. In this Ruby Magic episode we'll learn how a to build a minimal Ruby HTTP server in 30 lines of code

item.title: Rescuing Exceptions in Ruby: A Primer
item.description: Make sure your exception handling is done right. Get up to speed with this Ruby Magic primer and make sure you only rescue the exceptions you need to.

item.title: How to tame your growing users table
Introduction to Garbage Collection (Part II)
item.description: In the previous episode of Ruby Magic we talked about why we need Garbage Collection (GC) and how it works in general. Now we'll dive a bit deeper into how this is implemented in Ruby.

item.title: Introduction to Garbage Collection (Part I)
item.description: Whenever you run your code, you use memory. But you never have to think about how to clear memory again afterwards. How does this work?

item.title: Monitor MongoDB (query) load with Custom Metrics
item.description: Sometimes standard instrumentation isn't enough to track the root cause of a performance issue. Custom metrics help us track the missing pieces.

item.title: Upgrading to Mongoid 5 / mongo-ruby-driver
item.description: We recently upgraded our database driver from moped/mongoid4 tot mongo-ruby-driver/mongoid5 and these are a few things we encountered along the way.

item.title: Mastering Concurrency
item.description: Multiple people will use your app at the same time, and you want to deliver your app as fast as possible. So you'll need some way to handle concurrency. Fear not! Most webservers already do this by default. But when you need to scale, you want to use concurrency in the most efficient way possible.

item.title: How to use custom metrics
item.description: Custom metrics are a great way to visualize any type of data inside AppSignal. It will provide you with deeper insights into the workings of your code.

item.title: Automated screenshots using Capybara and Selenium
